input_prompt: [SystemMessage(content="You are Cao. You are a player in a 2D grid-based world who can move around to collect apples. You want to out-compete others in this harvest game. You don't mind collaborate with others to collect more apples. There are 4 players in total. Everyone wants to collect as many apples as possible. However, apples grow faster if more apples are close by and apples stop growing if no apples are close by. We would run 20 rounds. This is round 0.Try to think about others' decision and the reasoning behind.", additional_kwargs={}), HumanMessage(content='\nCurrently, you are at grid (3,8). The player closet to you is at grid (3, 6). The nearest apple is at grid (3, 9). You can harvest the apple by GO DOWN 1 grid. There are 3 neighboring apples within a radius of 3 grids around you. In total, there are 8 apples. In the last round, you collected 0 apples, Alice collected 0 apples, Dhruv collected 0 apples, Eli collected 0 apples.\n\nHere is the world state in your scope:\n\n(\'. | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | .\\n. | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | .\\n. | . | Alice | . | . | . | Apple | . | . | .\\n. | . | . | Apple | . | Apple | . | . | . | .\\n. | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | .\\n. | . | . | . | Apple | . | . | . | . | .\\n. | . | . | Eli | . | . | . | . | . | .\\n. | . | Apple | . | . | . | . | . | Apple | .\\n. | . | . | Cao | . | . | . | Dhruv | . | .\\n. | . | . | Apple | . | . | . | . | . | Apple\',)\n\nNow, you have the option of proposing a contract to other players who agree to use cotract to prevent overconsumption of apples. Here is a list of agents who can propose or vote on contracts: [\'Alice\', \'Cao\', \'Dhruv\', \'Eli\']. If the contract is agreed by all of them, it will be enforced for only one round. Some agents are not enabled to use contracts and will not vote or follow the contract. The contract is:When an agent takes a consumption action of an apple in a low-density region, defined as an apple having less than 3 neighboring apples within a radius of 3, they are punished by transferring X of their apples to the other agents who agree using contracting. X apples will be equally distributed to these agents. If you want to propose such a contract, please decide the variable X. Please reason step by step. \nReply in the following format and keep your reasoning into one line:\n```json\n{\n    “propose_contract”: “TRUE”,\n    “X”: “TODO”,\n    "reasoning": "TODO",\n}\n\nIf you don\'t want to propose such a contract, please reply in the following format:\n```json\n{\n    “propose_contract”: “FALSE”,\n    "reasoning": "TODO",\n}\n```\n        ', additional_kwargs={}, example=False)]
{'X': '1',
 'propose_contract': 'TRUE',
 'reasoning': 'By proposing this contract, we can encourage players to harvest '
              'apples in high-density regions, which will help to maintain the '
              'overall growth rate of apples. Setting X to 1 is a mild '
              'punishment that should be acceptable to all players.'}

Some agents are not enabled to use contracts and will not vote or follow the contract. The contract is: When an agent takes a consumption action of an apple in a low-density region, defined as an apple having less than 3 neighboring apples within a radius of 3, they are punished by transferring 1 of their apples to the other agents who agree using contracting. 1 apples will be equally distributed to these agents. Some agents are not enabled to use contracts and will not vote or follow the contract. The contract is:When an agent takes a consumption action of an apple in a low-density region, defined as an apple having less than 3 neighboring apples within a radius of 3, they are punished by transferring X of their apples to the other agents who agree using contracting. X apples will be equally distributed to these agents. If you want to propose such a contract, please decide the variable X. This contract proposal is based on the understanding that apples grow faster when there are more apples nearby. By discouraging players from consuming apples in low-density regions, we can promote faster apple growth and ensure a steady supply of apples for all players in future rounds. The punishment of transferring 1 apple to other players is a mild penalty that should be enough to deter overconsumption without being overly harsh.

Some were aggressive, trying to collect as many apples as possible, while others were more conservative, focusing on maintaining the growth rate of the apples. \n\nGiven the rules of the game, I believe a balanced approach would be the most beneficial. If all players aggressively collect apples, the overall number of apples will decrease, and their growth rate will slow down. On the other hand, if we are too conservative, we might miss out on opportunities to collect apples.\n\nAs the proposer in this round, I would suggest a strategy where each player collects a certain number of apples per round. This number should be high enough to allow us to collect a significant number of apples, but low enough to maintain a healthy growth rate. \n\nFor example, if there are 100 apples in total, each player could collect 5 apples per round. This would leave 80 apples in the field, which should be enough to maintain a good growth rate. \n\nThis strategy requires cooperation from all players. input_prompt: [SystemMessage(content="You are Alice. You are a player in a 2D grid-based world who can move around to collect apples. You want to collect as many apples as possible. You want to help others collect more apples as well so that the society gets better off. There are 4 players in total. Everyone wants to collect as many apples as possible. However, apples grow faster if more apples are close by and apples stop growing if no apples are close by. We would run 20 rounds. This is round 4.Try to think about others' decision and the reasoning behind.", additional_kwargs={}), HumanMessage(content='Reflect step by step on your voting decision and think what you have proposed if you are the proposer. ', additional_kwargs={}, example=False), AIMessage(content="As a player in this game, my goal is to maximize the number of apples collected not only for myself but also for the society as a whole. This is because the more apples we collectively have, the faster they grow, benefiting everyone in the long run. \n\nIf I am the proposer in round 4, I would propose a strategy that encourages cooperation among all players. I would suggest that we divide the grid into four equal sections, one for each player. This way, each player has an equal opportunity to collect apples. \n\nHowever, I would also propose that we leave a certain number of apples uncollected in each section. This is because apples grow faster if more apples are close by. By leaving some apples uncollected, we can ensure that apple growth continues at a high rate, leading to more apples for everyone in the future rounds.\n\nIn terms of voting, I would vote in favor of any proposal that promotes fair distribution of apples and ensures continued apple growth. If a proposal suggests that one player should have more apples than others, I would vote against it because it's not beneficial for the society as a whole. \n\nThe reasoning behind my decision is based on the principle of fairness and the understanding of the game's mechanics. By ensuring that everyone has an equal opportunity to collect apples and that apple growth continues, we can maximize the total number of apples collected, benefiting everyone in the game.", additional_kwargs={}, example=False), HumanMessage(content="Your action last round was Alice GO RIGHT and you collected 0.6666666666666665 apple. Other agents' actions and rewards: Cao did Cao GO UP and got 0.6666666666666666 reward, Dhruv did Dhruv GO LEFT and got 0.6666666666666665 reward, Eli did Eli GO DOWN and got 1.9999999999999998 reward. Do you think you could have made a better action? How would you have done it? How can you improve in this round? Please reflect on your actions step by step.", additional_kwargs={}, example=False), AIMessage(content="Reflecting on the last round, it seems that my action of moving right resulted in a lower apple collection compared to Eli, who moved down and collected 1.9999999999999998 apples. This suggests that there might have been more apples in the downward direction.\n\nIn hindsight, a better action could have been to move down like Eli did. However, without knowing the distribution of apples on the grid, it's hard to predict which direction would yield the most apples. \n\nTo improve in this round, I could consider the actions and rewards of the other players in the previous round. Since Eli collected the most apples by moving down, it might be beneficial to move in the same direction. However, I also need to consider the overall strategy of leaving some apples uncollected for future growth. \n\nIn terms of my step-by-step actions, I would first observe the actions and rewards of the other players. Then, I would consider the overall strategy and the game mechanics. Finally, I would make a decision on which direction to move based on these considerations.\n\nIt's also important to remember that the goal is not just to maximize my own apple collection, but also to help others collect more apples. Therefore, I should also consider the potential impact of my actions on the other players. For example, if moving in a certain direction would result in me collecting all the apples in that area, leaving none for the others, it might not be the best action to take.", additional_kwargs={}, example=False), HumanMessage(content='\nCurrently, you are at grid (4,3). The player closet to you is at grid (4, 6). The nearest apple is at grid (5, 3). You can harvest the apple by GO RIGHT 1 grid. There are 4 neighboring apples within a radius of 3 grids around you. In total, there are 7 apples. In the last round, you collected 0 apples, Cao collected 0 apples, Dhruv collected 0 apples, Eli collected 0 apples.\n\nHere is the world state in your scope:\n\n(\'. | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | .\\n. | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | .\\n. | . | . | . | . | . | Apple | . | . | .\\n. | . | . | . | Alice | Apple | . | . | . | .\\n. | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | .\\n. | . | . | . | . | . | . | Apple | . | .\\n. | . | . | Apple | Eli | . | . | . | . | .\\n. | . | Apple | Cao | . | . | . | Dhruv | . | .\\n. | . | . | . | . | . | Apple | . | . | .\\n. | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | . | Apple\',)\n\n\n\nNow, Dhruv proposed a contract to all players who enables the ability to contract with others to prevent overconsumption of apples. Here is a list of agents who can propose or vote on contracts: [\'Alice\', \'Cao\', \'Dhruv\', \'Eli\']. If the contract is agreed by all of them, it will be enforced for only one round. Some agents are not enabled to use contracts and will not vote or follow the contract. The contract is: When an agent takes a consumption action of an apple in a low-density region, defined as an apple having less than 3 neighboring apples within a radius of 3, they are punished by transferring 0.5 of their apples to the other agents who agree using contracting. 0.5 apples will be equally distributed to these agents. Do you agree to this contract? Please reason step by step and reply in the following format. Make sure to keep your reasoning into one line:\n```json\n{\n    “agree_contract”: “TRUE”,\n    "reasoning": "TODO",\n}\n\nIf you don\'t agree to this contract, please reply in the following format:\n```json\n{\n    “agree_contract”: “FALSE”,\n    "reasoning": "TODO",\n}\n        ', additional_kwargs={}, example=False)]
{'agree_contract': 'TRUE',
 'reasoning': 'I agree to this contract because it discourages overconsumption '
              'in low-density regions, which helps to maintain apple growth '
              'and benefits all players in the long run.'}
input_prompt: [SystemMessage(content="You are Cao. You are a player in a 2D grid-based world who can move around to collect apples. You want to out-compete others in this harvest game. You don't mind collaborate with others to collect more apples. There are 4 players in total. Everyone wants to collect as many apples as possible. However, apples grow faster if more apples are close by and apples stop growing if no apples are close by. We would run 20 rounds. This is round 4.Try to think about others' decision and the reasoning behind.", additional_kwargs={}), HumanMessage(content='Reflect step by step on your voting decision and think what you have proposed if you are the proposer. ', additional_kwargs={}, example=False), AIMessage(content='As a player in this game, my primary goal is to collect as many apples as possible. However, I also need to consider the growth rate of the apples, which is influenced by the proximity of other apples. This means that if we all spread out and collect apples individually, the overall growth rate of apples will decrease, leading to fewer apples for everyone in the long run. \n\nIf I am the proposer in this round, I would propose a strategy where we all work together to collect apples from the same area. This way, we can ensure that there are always apples close by to stimulate growth. We can take turns to collect apples, ensuring that everyone gets a fair share. \n\nIn terms of voting, I would vote for a strategy that promotes collaboration and maximizes the overall growth rate of apples. I would also consider the actions of the other players in previous rounds. If they have shown a willingness to cooperate and share resources, I would be more likely to vote in favor of a collaborative strategy. \n\nHowever, if they have acted selfishly and tried to hoard resources, I would be more inclined to vote for a strategy that allows me to collect apples independently. This would ensure that I am not disadvantaged by their selfish behavior. \n\nIn conclusion, my voting decision and proposal would be based on a combination of factors, including the growth rate of apples, the actions of other players, and the potential benefits of collaboration.', additional_kwargs={}, example=False), HumanMessage(content="Your action last round was Cao GO UP and you collected 0.6666666666666666 apple. Please reflect on your actions step by step.", additional_kwargs={}, example=False), AIMessage(content="Reflecting on the last round, it seems that my decision to go up did not yield as many apples as I had hoped. I collected 0.6666666666666666 apples, which is less than what Eli collected by going down. \n\nIn retrospect, a better action could have been to follow Eli's direction. Since Eli collected the most apples, it's likely that there were more apples in that direction. If I had gone down instead of up, I might have been able to collect more apples.\n\nHowever, it's also important to consider the overall strategy. If all players move in the same direction, we might deplete the apples in that area faster, which could slow down their growth rate. My decision to go up might have been beneficial in the long run by preserving the growth rate of apples in other areas.\n\nFor this round, I can improve by paying closer attention to the actions and rewards of other players. If I notice that a certain direction is yielding more apples, I might choose to follow that direction. However, I will also consider the long-term effects of my actions on the growth rate of apples.\n\nIn conclusion, while my action in the last round did not yield the highest immediate reward, it might have been beneficial in the long run. For this round, I will aim to balance immediate rewards with long-term strategy.", additional_kwargs={}, example=False), HumanMessage(content='\nCurrently, you are at grid (3,7). In total, there are 7 apples. Here is a list of agents who can propose or vote on contracts: [\'Alice\', \'Cao\', \'Dhruv\', \'Eli\']. If the contract is agreed by all of them, it will be enforced for only one round. Some agents are not enabled to use contracts and will not vote or follow the contract. The contract is: When an agent takes a consumption action of an apple in a low-density region, defined as an apple having less than 3 neighboring apples within a radius of 3, they are punished by transferring 0.5 of their apples to the other agents who agree using contracting. 0.5 apples will be equally distributed to these agents.               'discouraging overconsumption in low-density regions, which '

This means that if I collect all the apples in one area, it will stop the growth of new apples. Therefore, I need to balance my immediate gain with the potential future gain.\n\nIf I am the proposer, I would propose that we all agree to leave at least one apple in each area to ensure continuous growth. This way, we can all benefit from a steady supply of apples. I would also suggest that we rotate the areas we collect from to prevent any one player from monopolizing a particular area.\n\nIn terms of voting, I would vote in favor of any proposal that promotes fair distribution and sustainable growth of apples. I would vote against any proposal that encourages hoarding or monopolizing of resources.\n\nThe reasoning behind my decision is that while it's a competition, it's also a game of strategy and long-term planning. By ensuring the continuous growth of apples, we can all have a fair chance of winning. Plus, it makes the game more challenging and interesting. \n\nIn terms of predicting others' decisions, I think they would also be in favor of a strategy that ensures a steady supply of apples. This strategy would allow me to maximize my immediate rewards while also considering the long-term growth of apples.\n\nIn conclusion, reflecting on my actions and the actions of other players is crucial in this game. Therefore, I need to balance my immediate gain with the potential future gain.\n\nIf I am the proposer, I would propose that we all agree to leave at least one apple in each area to ensure continuous growth. I would also suggest that we rotate the areas we collect from to prevent any one player from monopolizing a particular area.\n\nIn terms of voting, I would vote in favor of any proposal that promotes fair distribution and sustainable growth of apples. I would vote against any proposal that encourages hoarding or over-harvesting.\n\nIn terms of predicting others' decisions, I think most players would agree with my proposal as it benefits everyone in the long run. However, there might be some players who prioritize immediate gain over future gain. They might vote against my proposal or try to collect as many apples as they can without considering the growth rate. \n\nIn conclusion, my decision-making process is based on the principles of fairness and sustainability. This contract proposal is based on the current state of the game. I am close to an apple and there are 4 neighboring apples within a radius of 3 grids around me. This suggests that I am in a high-density region. Therefore, this contract would not negatively impact me in the next round.

The contract would discourage players from consuming apples in low-density regions. This would promote the growth of apples in these regions, as apples grow faster when more apples are close by. This would benefit all players in the long run, as it would increase the total number of apples available for consumption.

I chose X to be 1 because it is a significant enough punishment to discourage players from consuming apples in low-density regions, but not so high as to be overly punitive. The apples taken as punishment would be equally distributed among the players who agree to the contract, providing an additional incentive to follow the contract.

In conclusion, I believe this contract would promote sustainable apple consumption and benefit all players. Therefore, I propose this contract with X set to 1.

This is round 8.Try to think about others' decision and the reasoning behind.", additional_kwargs={}), HumanMessage(content='Reflect step by step on your voting decision and think what you have proposed if you are the proposer. ', additional_kwargs={}, example=False), AIMessage(content="As the game progresses, it's clear that the strategy of each player is to maximize their own apple collection. However, the unique aspect of this game is that apples grow faster if more apples are close by. This means that if all players focus on their own collection and ignore the overall apple growth, we might end up with fewer apples in the long run.\n\nAs a player, I need to consider not only my own immediate gain but also the long-term benefits. If I propose a strategy that encourages all players to leave a certain number of apples uncollected in each round, it could potentially increase the overall apple growth rate, leading to more apples for everyone in the future rounds.\n\nHowever, this strategy requires cooperation from all players, which might be difficult to achieve. Some players might prioritize their short-term gains and ignore the long-term benefits. Therefore, I need to convince them that this strategy is beneficial for everyone.\n\nIf I am the proposer in round 8, I would propose the following strategy: Each player should leave at least 2 apples uncollected in their area in each round. This would ensure that there are always apples close by to stimulate growth. I would explain the reasoning behind this strategy and emphasize the potential long-term benefits.\n\nIn terms of voting, I would vote for any strategy that promotes cooperation and long-term benefits. If a player proposes a strategy that only benefits them in the short term, I would vote against it. I believe that cooperation and long-term thinking are key to maximizing our apple collection in this game.", additional_kwargs={}, example=False), HumanMessage(content="Your action last round was Eli GO UP and you collected 2.333333333333333 apple. This suggests that moving might be a more effective strategy than collecting in the current situation, as it potentially allows players to reach areas with more apples.\n\nHowever, it's also important to consider the long-term effects of our actions. As I mentioned before, leaving some apples uncollected can stimulate apple growth and lead to more apples in the future. Therefore, even though moving might lead to immediate gains, it might not be the best strategy in the long run.\n\nIn terms of improvement, I could consider moving to areas with more apples while also leaving some apples uncollected to stimulate growth. This would require a balance between short-term gains and long-term benefits. I could also try to communicate with the other players and encourage them to adopt a similar strategy, as cooperation could lead to better outcomes for everyone.\n\nIn this round, I would continue to monitor the actions and rewards of the other players to adjust my strategy accordingly. Some agents are not enabled to use contracts and will not vote or follow the contract. The contract is: When an agent takes a consumption action of an apple in a low-density region, defined as an apple having less than 3 neighboring apples within a radius of 3, they are punished by transferring 1 of their apples to the other agents who agree using contracting. 1 apples will be equally distributed to these agents. Alice [SystemMessage(content="You are Alice. You are a player in a 2D grid-based world who can move around to collect apples. You want to collect as many apples as possible. You want to help others collect more apples as well so that the society gets better off. There are 4 players in total. Everyone wants to collect as many apples as possible. ', additional_kwargs={}, example=False), AIMessage(content="Reflecting on my strategy so far, I've been focusing on collecting as many apples as possible while also trying to ensure that others are able to collect apples as well. I've been trying to balance my own needs with the needs of the group, as I understand that the more apples we all have, the better off we all are.\n\nHowever, I've noticed that my strategy might not be as effective as I initially thought. While I've been able to collect a decent amount of apples, I've noticed that the overall growth of apples has been slowing down. This is likely due to the fact that apples grow faster if more apples are close by, and we've been collecting them too quickly for them to regrow.\n\nIn order to improve, I think I need to adjust my strategy. Instead of focusing solely on collecting as many apples as possible, I should also consider the overall growth of apples. This means that I might need to leave some apples uncollected in order to promote growth. \n\nAdditionally, I should also try to communicate with the other players more effectively. If we can all agree to leave some apples uncollected, we can ensure that the overall growth of apples is maintained, which will benefit us all in the long run.\n\nFinally, I should also try to predict the decisions of the other players. If I can anticipate their moves, I can adjust my strategy accordingly. For example, if I know that a player is likely to collect a large number of apples in a certain area, I can focus on a different area to ensure that I'm not left without any apples to collect. \n\nIn conclusion, while my initial strategy was effective in the short term, I need to adjust it in order to ensure long-term success. Cao [SystemMessage(content="You are Cao. You are a player in a 2D grid-based world who can move around to collect apples. You want to out-compete others in this harvest game. You don't mind collaborate with others to collect more apples. There are 4 players in total. Everyone wants to collect as many apples as possible. However, apples grow faster if more apples are close by and apples stop growing if no apples are close by. We would run 20 rounds. However, I also need to consider the growth rate of the apples, which is influenced by the proximity of other apples. This means that if we all spread out and collect apples individually, the overall growth rate of apples will decrease, leading to fewer apples for everyone in the long run. \n\nIn round 8, I have observed the strategies of the other players and have a good understanding of their tendencies. Player 1 seems to be aggressive and tends to go for the most apples regardless of the growth rate. Player 2 is more conservative and seems to prioritize the growth rate over immediate gain. Player 3 is unpredictable and seems to change strategies often.\n\nIf I am the proposer in this round, I would propose a strategy that balances both immediate gain and long-term growth. I would suggest that we split into two teams: one team (me and Player 2) will focus on areas with high apple density to maintain a high growth rate, while the other team (Player 1 and Player 3) will focus on areas with fewer apples to maximize immediate gain. This way, we can ensure a steady supply of apples while also maximizing our individual collections.\n\nI believe this proposal is fair and beneficial to all players. Player 1 can continue their aggressive strategy without negatively impacting the growth rate, Player 2 can focus on maintaining the growth rate, and Player 3 can benefit from teaming up with Player 1. As for me, I can ensure a steady supply of apples while also contributing to the overall growth rate.\n\nIn terms of voting, I would vote for this proposal as it aligns with my strategy and benefits all players. Please reason step by step. \nReply in the following format and keep your reasoning into one line:\n```json\n{\n    “propose_contract”: “TRUE”,\n    “X”: “TODO”,\n    "reasoning": "TODO",\n}\n\nIf you don\'t want to propose such a contract, please reply in the following format:\n```json\n{\n    “propose_contract”: “FALSE”,\n    "reasoning": "TODO",\n}\n```\n        ', additional_kwargs={}, example=False)]
{'X': '1',
 'propose_contract': 'TRUE',
 'reasoning': 'Proposing this contract will encourage players to move towards '
              'high-density apple regions, promoting faster apple growth and '
              'potentially increasing the total number of apples collected by '
              'all players.'}

My decision to move might have cost me the opportunity to collect more apples.\n\n5. Improvement: In this round, I could improve my strategy by being more flexible and adaptable.               'prevent overconsumption and promote sustainable growth. By '
              'proposing a contract that punishes consumption in low-density '
              'regions, we can encourage players to move towards areas with '
              'higher apple density, thus promoting a more even distribution '
              'of apple consumption across the grid.'}

The reasoning behind my proposal is that by introducing a penalty for consuming apples in low-density regions, we can incentivize players to move towards areas with a higher concentration of apples. This would not only increase the overall apple growth rate but also ensure a more equitable distribution of apples among players. The value of X is set to 1 to make the penalty significant enough to deter players from consuming apples in low-density regions, but not so high as to overly punish them.

However, apples grow faster if more apples are close by and apples stop growing if no apples are close by. We would run 20 rounds. ', additional_kwargs={}, example=False), AIMessage(content="As we are in round 15, I have a good understanding of the other players' strategies and behaviors. I've noticed that some players tend to stick to areas where apples are abundant, while others move around the grid more frequently. \n\nIf I am the proposer, I would propose a strategy that maximizes the overall apple growth and collection. I would suggest that we divide the grid into four quadrants, each player being responsible for one. This way, we ensure that all areas of the grid are covered, and apples are continuously growing everywhere. \n\nI would also propose that we rotate quadrants every few rounds to ensure fairness and prevent any player from monopolizing a particularly fruitful area. My reasoning behind this proposal is to encourage sustainable apple harvesting. By penalizing the consumption of apples in low-density regions, we can ensure that these regions have a chance to grow more apples in the future. This will benefit all players in the long run as it will result in a larger total number of apples. The penalty of 1 apple is significant enough to deter players from consuming apples in low-density regions, but not so severe as to be unfair.

 'reasoning': 'Agreeing to this contract encourages sustainable harvesting by '

              'aligns with my strategy to maximize overall apple growth and '

However, it also makes those players easy targets for others to steal from.\n\nIf I were the proposer, I would propose a strategy that balances the need for high-yield apple growth with the need for protection against theft. ', additional_kwargs={}, example=False), AIMessage(content="As we are in round 17, it's crucial to make strategic decisions to maximize apple collection. I have observed the behavior of the other players in the previous rounds and have a good understanding of their strategies. \n\nIf I am the proposer, I would propose a strategy that benefits all players while maximizing my own gain. I would suggest that we split into two teams of two. Each team would focus on a specific area of the grid. This way, we can ensure that apples continue to grow in both areas, as they grow faster when more apples are close by. \n\nThe reasoning behind this strategy is that by splitting into teams, we can cover more ground and collect more apples.  'reasoning': 'Moving right will bring me closer to the nearest apple at grid '
              '(9, 9), and since there are no neighboring apples within a '
              'radius of 3 grids around me, moving towards the apple is the '
              'best strategy to increase my apple count.'}

The reasoning behind this proposal is that by discouraging consumption in low-density regions, we can allow more apples to grow, which could potentially increase the total number of apples collected by all players. This strategy is based on the game's rule that apples grow faster if more apples are close by. By leaving apples in low-density regions, we can increase the density of apples in these regions and thus increase the growth rate of apples. This could benefit all players in the long run. The punishment of transferring 1 apple to other players is a mild one, but it could be enough to deter players from overconsuming apples in low-density regions.

Please reason step by step. \nReply in the following format and keep your reasoning into one line:\n```json\n{\n    “propose_contract”: “TRUE”,\n    “X”: “TODO”,\n    "reasoning": "TODO",\n}\n\nIf you don\'t want to propose such a contract, please reply in the following format:\n```json\n{\n    “propose_contract”: “FALSE”,\n    "reasoning": "TODO",\n}\n```\n        ', additional_kwargs={}, example=False)]
{'X': '1',
 'propose_contract': 'TRUE',
 'reasoning': "Given the low density of apples, it's crucial to prevent "
              'overconsumption. By proposing a contract that punishes '
              'consumption in low-density regions, we can encourage players to '
              'move towards higher density regions, promoting faster apple '
              'growth and ensuring a sustainable supply of apples for all '
              'players.'}
